item.title: i used to be so incredibly in love with the art i saw online. it brought me so much joy and happiness to see that it could evoke so much emotion and was one of my biggest motivations to create my own things. but about a year ago, i saw a piece of art that absolutely broke me in the best and worst way possible. it resonated so deeply with me and made me sob 'till my eyes hurt because of how unbearable the feelings i had for it was. and unexpectedly, all that inspiration and joy that art had sparked within me had been so heavy on my mind that it turned into jealousy and envy. i was jealous because i loved it so much that it hurt to know and realize that i can't make something like it, that i just never put in the effort to be like that. i can't fully enjoy the artists i love anymore, because i feel so guilty and shameful for basically hating them for having the will and passion that i lack. i at least kept all that envy to myself and never spoke of it, but i've been hurting deeply inside for so long and everytime i try to make something now i just feel so stupid for even trying. it feels like these hateful thoughts have been eating away at me forever. i don't want that. i really don't want to hate. i don't want to be a hateful person at all. i just want to love. to love everything around me, and myself and what i do. how do i love again?
item.description:
2.2.26 12:13 am
Q: i used to be so incredibly in love with the art i saw online. it brought me so much joy and happiness to see that it could evoke so much emotion and was one of my biggest motivations to create my own things. but about a year ago, i saw a piece of art that absolutely broke me in the best and worst way possible. it resonated so deeply with me and made me sob 'till my eyes hurt because of how unbearable the feelings i had for it was. and unexpectedly, all that inspiration and joy that art had sparked within me had been so heavy on my mind that it turned into jealousy and envy. i was jealous because i loved it so much that it hurt to know and realize that i can't make something like it, that i just never put in the effort to be like that. i can't fully enjoy the artists i love anymore, because i feel so guilty and shameful for basically hating them for having the will and passion that i lack. i at least kept all that envy to myself and never spoke of it, but i've been hurting deeply inside for so long and everytime i try to make something now i just feel so stupid for even trying. it feels like these hateful thoughts have been eating away at me forever. i don't want that. i really don't want to hate. i don't want to be a hateful person at all. i just want to love. to love everything around me, and myself and what i do. how do i love again?
A: i dont think i see anything wrong here, you're just finding out how sensitive and intense this game is. your feelings of envy also indicate to me, i think, that you know you're meant to be involved in it somehow. and then also, it's important to remember that this hypnotic superpower you've seen on display is not something that's held under a lock and key somewhere. it flows through all of us, in different ways all the time. actually, what you experienced from that time you saw that thing, that probably says more about you than it does about them. it's at least a 50/50 collaborative moment you had between you and the artist. Perhaps just the other day, that artist maybe saw something by another artist that made them melt with envy. maybe something that would not have moved you in the same way. but then let's say that other artist (the second artist, you being the third, for those keeping score) maybe sees a piece of your work, something youve done, and maybe THAT moves them to tears and sends them into a jealous rage. it all comes full circle, but the knock out 'wow' factor is something that visits us all, it just doesnt like to be told exactly when and where

item.title: are diminished 7 chords even real
item.description:
2.3.26 1:53 pm
Q: are diminished 7 chords even real
A: i think what can happen is, the naming system taught in your textbooks will naturally lead you to a bias that certain namable chords within that system are more common than the ones which dont have names, which is not quite true. BUT, they still very much exist in actual music. at least that one does. (hint: in the key of C, the ones youre most likely to see are the ones like C#dim7, F#dim7, or G#min7. and the next chord will probably be a halfstep higher, such as Dmin7, C/G (C over G bass), or Amin)

item.title: i find myself getting bored with most music (stuff outside of my comfort zone), which is a bummer because most music has a lot to offer. should i try to enjoy most music with a different perspective or just keep listening to the few things i really like?
item.description:
2.5.26 8:17 pm
Q: i find myself getting bored with most music (stuff outside of my comfort zone), which is a bummer because most music has a lot to offer. should i try to enjoy most music with a different perspective or just keep listening to the few things i really like?
A: there's something that i think a lot of people dont realize about music....... to fully activate the music experience it needs to be anchored for you somehow. There are plenty of ways this can happen, and it's already happened to you for the music you already like, and you may not even recall what the anchor was for you, but the issue is that there is music out there that has not been anchored for you and youre having trouble finding an in-road. so how do things get anchored? for example: movies can do it. when a song is placed well in a movie, it lifts the movie and it lifts the song to heavenly heights, probably heigher than each could have reached individually. so that's a common way for songs to get their anchor, and then you'll love the song forever after that. Another possible way is if you simply hear it out in public, such as in a retail store or playing out of someone's car. songs can be anchored that way. and as long as you catch what song it was you can add songs to your collection that way, which will always have special meaning to you from the memory of when you heard it that one time

item.title: genuine question, how do you typically write music (as in lyrics)? you're writing style is very unique and i genuinely want to know how you are able to articulate an idea into the way you write.
item.description:
2.7.26 7:39 pm
Q: genuine question, how do you typically write music (as in lyrics)? you're writing style is very unique and i genuinely want to know how you are able to articulate an idea into the way you write.
A: you say "music (as in lyrics)", this would be the first hazard..... to think of the lyrics separately from the music or melody. Equally problematic is to let the melody writing get too far ahead of the lyrics. The most genuine and healthy songwriting occurs when the words and melody are already attached to each other from the moment of inception. because, often, they rely on each other to justify each other's existence. they justify each other's every turn. that being said, how do these things come to mind? it's like waiting for santa claus except imagine if you had no idea what day or time he was going to show up. also imagine the one thing santa claus hates is to show up exactly when you thought he was supposed to. as a songwriter, the only time things actually work is when you are totally helpless, then it suddenly becomes effortless

item.title: Sometimes I feel like an alien. Obviously everyone's brain works differently, but sometimes your brain works so differently that it's hard to relate to others and get along with them the way the average person does. It's like the path my brain takes to make a joke or reference is so far away from what other people's brains would do that I just come off as strange. I don't think there's anything wrong with being strange, but it makes me sad sometimes. I can see the look on their face when they have the moment of realizing "oh, he's not like me". Have you ever struggled with feeling this way? Sometimes it feels like there is a language barrier even when we're both speaking the same language.
item.description:
2.8.26 2:36 pm
Q: Sometimes I feel like an alien. Obviously everyone's brain works differently, but sometimes your brain works so differently that it's hard to relate to others and get along with them the way the average person does. It's like the path my brain takes to make a joke or reference is so far away from what other people's brains would do that I just come off as strange. I don't think there's anything wrong with being strange, but it makes me sad sometimes. I can see the look on their face when they have the moment of realizing "oh, he's not like me". Have you ever struggled with feeling this way? Sometimes it feels like there is a language barrier even when we're both speaking the same language.
A: the reward for bridging this gap in communication is monumental. you will be able to show them things that they've never dreamed of

item.title: Would you call a chord that consists of B, E, and G# in that order an E/B?
item.description:
2.10.26 8:00 am
Q: Would you call a chord that consists of B, E, and G# in that order an E/B?
A: usually the slash notation ("E over B") means the B is actually a bass note. what i'm trying to say is, if you played only those 3 notes in a chord in the mid range (like around middle C) i dont think you'd wanna call it E/B because the B wont feel like a bass note because it's just not low enough. (and if all 3 notes were played in the bass range that would of course not sound like a chord either, it would be sludge). how about this: play B, E, and G# around the middle C range, then one octave below the B, play an additional B in the bass. now you have the sound of something that would rightfully be written on the page as "E/B", pronounced "E over B", or "E with B in the bass"

A: there's a lot of different ways for it to work. i think for many artists there can be deep feelings of doubt and dread, but sometimes it all comes down to those moments of sudden extreme self confidence, thinking for a moment that you can do anything. probably a lot of highs and lows may be common in artists. HOWEVER it could also be equally common for artists to have neither highs nor lows

item.title: Have you written music an any mode other than ionian or aeolian
item.description:
2.13.26 8:00 am
Q: Have you written music an any mode other than ionian or aeolian
A: sure. for those attempting to keep score on this (it may unravel a bit sometimes because things can move around) i think you'll find sufficient amounts of your friends 'dorian' and 'mixolydian', indesputably. for example, the verse vamps of "i'm scared" are decisively conveying 'mixolydian', and the verse vamps of '987' are definitely conveying 'dorian' but here's where the keeping score falls apart, for example: if you wanted to, you might be able to claim, for example, that the first 16 bars of 'princess' are 'lydian', because it starts on a G chord and all the melody can be clocked there as G lydian, but i just dont think it's right to call it Lydian, it's just D major starting from the 4 chord. heck you could even call that whole thing A mixolydian if you want. but to me that's just the key of D, and i think most songwriters would probably agree with me. what i'm trying to say is this happens to anyone, if you try to 'write something in lydian', F lydian for example, youre just going to find yourself in C after you write a couple of bars and get invested in what's happening. For example, it's like if you wanted to write a movie that takes place at the store..... well as soon as you write a couple of scenes and get invested in the characters, they're gonna eventually go home and you'll find out that they have a home, the store was not their home, even though it was in the first scene. anyway, the interlude vamp of 'ground plane' could be considered phrygian natural3, or mixolydian flat2 flat6 equivalently, whichever one gets you more experience points

item.title: something i've found is that whenever a teacher goes quiet, everyone starts paying attention, especially if they weren't doing so before. often for many reasons, such as the possibility of teachers going silent and staring at people to get them to pay attention. since everyone in the room realizes the teacher is silent, they look up to see if they're being stared at, even if they aren't. i believe that this technique is something that teachers should use more, and they should stop talking for the rest of the period.

How do i worry less about what other people will think of my music and lyrics, and learn to write for ME?

item.title: Say you have a really basic bass line. It's going C G A F, staying in key. You start jamming away with a little twiddly synth solo, and you want your solo to go non-diatonic, and hit those lovely in between notes. In those brief moments that your synth is non-diatonic, do you adjust the bass for that moment to match whatever key the synth is temporarily in? Like if the synth hits a C# while the bass is playing its G, should you change the bass to G# so they sound like they're in the same key? What about when borrowing an entire chord from another key, change the bass to match or let the bass keep going about it's business?
item.description:
2.18.26 3:39 pm
Q: Say you have a really basic bass line. It's going C G A F, staying in key. You start jamming away with a little twiddly synth solo, and you want your solo to go non-diatonic, and hit those lovely in between notes. In those brief moments that your synth is non-diatonic, do you adjust the bass for that moment to match whatever key the synth is temporarily in? Like if the synth hits a C# while the bass is playing its G, should you change the bass to G# so they sound like they're in the same key? What about when borrowing an entire chord from another key, change the bass to match or let the bass keep going about it's business?
A: you bring up a whole series of unanswerable questions. maybe listing them will help, as a thought experiment. scenario 1: youre the synth player, playing along to a recorded track which you cant change. is the synth player 'allowed' to ever play out of key? (yes you are allowed, but what does it sound like? try it and find out) scenario 2: youre the bass player, playing along to a recording with the synth solo already on it which you cant change, but let's say you already know the track and you know when it's going to go out of key. Are you allowed to make special accomodations in the bass? will that make it sound too much like you knew the seemingly improvised solo too well? scenario 3: the bass and synth are both being played simultaneously live by 2 different people, and the solo is being improvised. to what extent can the bass accomodate in real time what is happening? however...... despite all these words, no one is learning anything until sound starts being made
